questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A workstation downloads a malicious .docx file from the Internet and a copy is sent to FTDv. The FTDv sends the file hash to FMC and the file event is recorded. What would have occurred with stronger data visibility?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
i'd go with D. it's about visibility, not protection

Selected Answer: B
The question already gave us the information that the file is Malicious,  yet it has not been blocked and has just been recorded by FMC.

If we had stronger data visibility, detailed information about the data in real time would have been provided, and malicious traffic would have been blocked on multiple devices.

This is indeed a tricky question, but I do think that it asks what the "End Result" here  if there is stronger data visibility.

Selected Answer: D
With stronger data visibility, the security team would have more detailed and real-time information about the malicious .docx file, allowing them to better detect, analyze, and respond to the threat. This could include more granular information about the file's characteristics, behavior, and network traffic patterns, as well as visibility across multiple devices and network segments. This could help to improve threat detection and response capabilities and enhance overall security posture.

So, why not B?
Option B could also be a possible answer, as stronger data visibility could enable multiple devices to block malicious traffic. However, option D more accurately describes the benefits of stronger data visibility in this specific scenario, as it mentions providing detailed information about the data in real time. Option D emphasizes the importance of having a comprehensive view of network traffic and being able to quickly identify and respond to potential threats.

Selected Answer: D
The question is what would have occurred with stronger data visibility. Not what should be implemented for better protection.

Selected Answer: D
could be a D aswell

Selected Answer: C
The question asks about stronger visibility not better protection.
The question states "stronger data visibility" so not better protection. So I would assume the answer could be C too?

Selected Answer: B
B. Malicious traffic would have been blocked on multiple devices.

choices.C: The traffic would have been monitored at any segment in the network.
choices.B: Malicious traffic would have been blocked on multiple devices.
choices.D: Detailed information about the data in real time would have been provided.
choices.A: An extra level of security would have been in place.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. 14, 16, 18, and 19

I think it's A.
Wireshark captures and displays network traffic at the packet level. If you extract a file from a TCP stream within Wireshark, you are extracting the content of the captured packets related to that particular file transfer. The extracted file will include the data payload from the frames within the TCP stream.

D
"contain a file that is extractable" does not include the request thu.

Selected Answer: D
It' should be D.

Selected Answer: B
B. 7 and 21

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which frame numbers contain a file that is extractable via TCP stream within Wireshark?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A

A
The use of NULL queries in DNS traffic, also known as NULL QTYPE or QTYPE 10, can be associated with certain DNS tunneling or reconnaissance techniques. While NULL queries are part of the DNS protocol (defined in RFC 1035), their usage for legitimate purposes is limited. When NULL queries are observed in DNS traffic, it might indicate potential security concerns or be associated with specific attacks

Selected Answer: A
It's the same picture used in hack.lu CTF:
Here the write-up (already mentioned by "weganos" in his comment) where it's explained the DNS tunnel technique:
Hack.lu CTF - Challenge 9 "bottle" writeup, extracting data from an iodine DNS tunnel
(https://blog.stalkr.net/2010/10/hacklu-ctf-challenge-9-bottle-writeup.html)

comments.content: my fault. i meant to say response, not request.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Comparing PCAPS of Amplification VS Tunneling, it's clear that Amplification involves many standard query responses and MANY less queries. DNS Tunneling is much more feasible in this situation because of the back and forth communication between source and dest. and the conversation of QUERY > REQUEST > QUERY > REQUEST and so forth.

Selected Answer: B
DNS tunneling involves using the DNS protocol to create a covert communication channel between two endpoints. This is achieved by encoding data within DNS queries or responses, which can then be sent between the endpoints without detection by security systems. DNS tunneling can be used to bypass firewalls, exfiltrate data, or carry out other malicious activities.

DNS amplification, on the other hand, involves exploiting the characteristics of the DNS protocol to amplify the volume of traffic directed at a target server. This is achieved by sending a small DNS query to a DNS server that is configured to respond with a much larger DNS response. The attacker can then spoof the source IP address of the query, causing the amplified response to be sent to the target server. This can result in a DDoS (Distributed Denial of Service) attack, where the target server is overwhelmed with traffic and becomes unavailable to legitimate users.

Selected Answer: A
In the case of DNS amplification, the log file would show a large number of requests coming from a spoofed source IP address, directed at open DNS resolvers. The responses from the resolvers would be much larger than the requests, resulting in a high volume of traffic being sent to the target.

Similarly in DNS tunneling, the log file would show a large number of DNS requests and responses, but with a much lower volume of traffic compared to an amplification attack. Additionally, the logs would show that the *requests and responses contain data* that is not typical of normal DNS traffic, indicating that it is being used to exfiltrate data.

Is this an actual CISCO question? It seems to be a CTF on Hack.lu. Here's a write-up: https://blog.stalkr.net/2010/10/hacklu-ctf-challenge-9-bottle-writeup.html

The Answer is A: DNS tunneling

Selected Answer: A
host is just contacting c2 via domain names and then later on there are entries showing data exfil via dns

Selected Answer: B
B should be the right answer.

Selected Answer: B
Lots of responses mean amplification.
DNS Tunneling is right

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. What is occurring?

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer is analyzing a PCAP file after a recent breach. An engineer identified that the attacker used an aggressive ARP scan to scan the hosts and found web and SSH servers. Further analysis showed several SSH Server Banner and Key Exchange Initiations. The engineer cannot see the exact data being transmitted over an encrypted channel and cannot identify how the attacker gained access. How did the attacker gain access?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
It's B

cant be A as its openssh
cant be C as packets are small so there is no overflow happening (anyway its openssh and not ssh workstion which was into this issue)
cant be D as silent redirecting was used 20 years ago with ssh v1

looks like B

Selected Answer: B
I don't know who is making this questions but this one is very tricky and with lack of information.
Have no clue who select D as correct but the vulnerabilty described in D answe is very old and have affected SSH versions prior 2. From packet capture, the SSH v is 2 - so not vulnerable.
About A answer, we can see from the packet capture the server is OpenSSH and not Tectia and also running on Linux (true that Tectia has some vulns for Linux/Unix but those are affecting versions 6.x)
So the only remaining valid answer, IMHO, given the dozens of RST,ACK in such a short time, followed by a success connection is B - a brute force which succeeded

Selected Answer: A
Undoubtedly A

The exhibit shows SSHv2. According to CVEDetails --> https://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2001-1474/ before v2 was possible to to silently redirect connections to the localhost by poisoning the client's DNS cache.
D. by using an SSH vulnerability to silently redirect connections to the local host

choices.B: by using brute force on the SSH service to gain access
choices.D: by using an SSH vulnerability to silently redirect connections to the local host
choices.C: by using the buffer overflow in the URL catcher feature for SSH
choices.A: by using an SSH Tectia Server vulnerability to enable host-based authentication
